headline.main: Phys Ed: Not What It Used to Be

docs.lead_paragraph: TAMMIE Williams, a junior at Hackensack High School in New Jersey, wanted to strengthen her stomach muscles and thighs, so she began using a routine thatincludes a stairclimber, leg press and toe raises. Loredana Giangrande's aerobics class at the high school has helped her lose six pounds. "It relaxes me," she said of the class, which is held in a large room with mirrored walls and a sound system for music that accompanies the exercises. "I get migraine headaches, but when I'm in aerobics class, they go away."

headline.main: The 90's Woman: How Fat Is Fat?

docs.lead_paragraph: BITE by bite, American women dutifully serve the reigning image of body beautiful. Men have been almost blissfully immune from the vicissitudes of body style, but in the United States women have borne the burden with gusto. In the late 19th century, when the fleshy physique dominated, the generous Gibson Girl contours were sought with a flurry of forks. "The lean are restless and irritable in mind, rarely contented, never quiet," admonished "How to Be Plump: Or Talks on Physiological Feeding," an 1878 handbook by Dr. T. C. Duncan. "They form the complaining element of society, and are unstable as a nation." When thin came in, women used their forks to push food primly from one side of the plate to the other. "It makes me feel powerful to be hungry," an emaciated Ivana Trump told reporters in 1986.
